Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 10:44AM kerryanne wrote: I agree completely with the other women who have posted. As hard as it is to slow down now, that's what has to happen. (And believe me, I've been where you are, with my gut and brain all tied into knots as I waited for a biopsy--my little kids gathered around me and every possible scenario playing out in my mind. It's a horrible time. Waiting is just the worst!) But for your well-being, it has to be one step at a time. You need a diagnosis from a pathologist looking at tissue from the biopsy under a microscope before you make any decisions. The news there is likely to be good, since women in their 30s develop non-cancer breast changes all the time, while only a very few develop cancer. The surgeon can't tell for sure just what's going on just by looking during the surgery. Even areas that feel very suspicious on breast exam and look bad on mammograms and even during surgery often turn out to be completely benign, not cancer at all. While occasionally surgeons order a "frozen section," a quick read of the tissue while the patient is in surgery, it's much less accurate than the standard procedure, which takes a few days. When you have a firm diagnosis from the pathologist, you can relax (benign!) or decide on more action if necessary. In any case, your family history, any inherited genetic mutation, and other risk factors need to be part of your decision process. I send you every good wish!
Posts.Title: New and playing the waiting game!! fancyfree77 somethingnew

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 12:38PM kerryanne wrote: Almost always, "lumps" or thickenings that are under the nipple in the same spot on both breasts and have been there for years have nothing to do with cancer. They may very well just be the way your breasts are developing or something else pretty simple. But do check it out with your doctor or other health care provider. I suspect you will be reassured--and you have been worrying about this for way too long! It's not worth it!
